slidelink.displaytext: What percentage of higher education officials feel that academic dishonesty is a serious issue?

search.slidetext: discouraging academic dishonesty through design trista sears image attribution: https://www.pexels.com/photo/a-person-cheating-in-an-exam-6684210/
introduction

remove distractions turn off your phone, close your door, and let those around you know that you will be unavailable for a while. image attribution: https://www.pexels.com/photo/a-white-and-black-text-box-8296048/
technology requirements to be successful in this lesson, you will need access to a computer, a robust internet connection, and speakers. computer internet speakers/headphones

successful completion students must complete both modules, all learning activities, and score an 80% on the summative assessment. image attribution: https://www.pexels.com/photo/woman-writing-on-her-notebook-3059747/

introductions atsumi will make appearances during activities. introduce yourself to atsumi by filling in the name tag below. image attribution: https://openclipart.org/detail/250091/hello-my-name-is type your name here

activity directions: on the next slide, click and drag the slider to answer the question. question: using the slider, indicate how much of a problem that you think academic dishonesty is in higher education today.
activity question: how much of a problem do you think academic dishonesty is in higher education today? i’m not really sure!?! no problem at all! a really big problem

academic dishonesty mccabe et al. (2006) found that 56% of graduate business students admitted to some form of cheating in the last year. image attribution:https://www.pexels.com/photo/students-cheating-during-an-exam-7092544/
triggering phase

thank you 34% of higher education officials feel that academic dishonesty is an issue. this is lower than the 41% of the general american public who feel the same way. continue continue continue continue continue continue percent what percentage of higher education officials feel that academic dishonesty is a serious issue? what do the officials say?
academic dishonesty academic dishonesty is prevalent in higher education, but there are steps that we can take to discourage it. plagiarism detection software assignment design assessment design
turnitin turnitin is a plagiarism-detection software that generates a similarity report for written assignments.

thank you my goal today is to help you become more comfortable with turnitin and the turnitin similarity reports; maybe you will pick up some new ideas. continue continue continue continue continue continue uncomfortable somewhat uncomfortable not sure of my feelings somewhat comfortable comfortable answer box instructions: drag and drop the word or phrase into the box provided that best completes the sentence for you personally. there are no right or wrong answers. question: right now, i am ___________ with turnitin and interpreting the similarity report.

discouraging academic dishonesty i will talk about ways to discourage academic dishonesty and how to create assignments/assessments that do just that. image attribution:https://www.pexels.com/photo/teacher-proctoring-his-students-during-an-examination-7092581/
what are some ways that i can create assignments or assessments that discourage academic dishonesty?
some ways that i can create assignments or assessments that discourage academic dishonesty are… %textentry1%

learning objectives after completing this lesson, you will be able to: define plagiarism. interpret a turnitin report. describe ways to create assignments that discourage plagiarism and the use of ai. identify ways to create assessments that discourage academic dishonesty.
exploration phase

progress let’s get started please select module 1 below to begin. module 2 will unlock once module 1 has been completed. module 1 turnitin module 1 turnitin module 1 turnitin module 1 turnitin module 1 turnitin module 1 turnitin module 1 turnitin module 2 prevention strategies module 2 prevention strategies module 2 prevention strategies module 2 prevention strategies module 2 prevention strategies module 2 prevention strategies module 2 prevention strategies finish finish finish finish finish finish 1: %mod1complete% 2: %mod2complete%
module 1: turnitin

drag and drop activity directions: on the next slide, drag the statements that best represent your feelings to the my feelings box. when you are finished, click submit. question: what are your feelings on the implementation of turnitin?

thank you thank you for your response. continue continue continue continue continue continue what are your feelings on the implementation of turnitin? i’m curious i don’t think it’s necessary i don’t like it i think it creates more work i think it’s a great idea i don’t have a problem with plagiarism in my class. i’m not sure that i would recognize all instances of plagiarism. my feelings on turnitin
what is turnitin? turnitin is a plagiarism-detection software that is commonly used in educational settings. image attribution: www.turnitin.com

how it works compares student’s work against content databases, student papers, internet archives, and scholarly publications. image attribution: https://www.pexels.com/photo/an-organized-brown-wooden-drawers-6333856/
similarity report the similarity report is the result of the comparisons of the student’s work against the turnitin databases.

let’s explore click on the question marks to explore the different sections of the turnitin similarity report. percentage of similarity this is the percentage of the submitted work that matches a database entry. text that is similar the text that is similar to database entries is highlighed in different colors. different colors represent different sources. original source the original source, database entry, article, webpage, or paper is listed here with the link to the source, if applicable. the source is color-matched to the highlighting in the text.
using similarity scores we must use our discretion when interpreting similarity scores. image attribution: https://www.pexels.com/photo/photo-of-woman-in-yellow-shirt-thinking-deeply-3808013/
tricking turnitin students can use strategies to get work that is not original through turnitin. image attribution: https://help.turnitin.com/feedback-studio/flags.htm#example
turnitin flags turnitin has been developed to pick up character substitutions, and hidden letters.
integrity report replaced characters, hidden text, and non-standard spellings of words are identified in the flags section of the integrity report.

other considerations if a student uses an essay mill or a ghost writer, turnitin may classify the document as original. image attribution: https://www.pexels.com/photo/a-red-sale-tag-on-a-miniature-shopping-cart-placed-on-a- macbook-laptop-5632381/
module 2: prevention strategies

discouraging academic dishonesty academic dishonesty can be discouraged through the design of the assessments and assignments. image attribution: https://images.pexels.com/photos/7092612/pexels-photo-7092612.jpeg?auto=compress&cs= tinysrgb&w=600&lazy=load

be proactive don’t be afraid to talk to your students about academic dishonesty; let them know that you are informed. image attribution: https://www.pexels.com/photo/photo-of-men-having-conversation-935949/

let’s dig deeper please select lesson 1 below to begin. lesson 2 will unlock once lesson 1 has been completed. lesson 1 assessment lesson 1 assessment lesson 1 assessment lesson 1 assessment lesson 1 assessment lesson 1 assessment lesson 1 assessment lesson 2 assignments lesson 2 assignments lesson 2 assignments lesson 2 assignments lesson 2 assignments lesson 2 assignments lesson 2 assignments continue continue continue continue continue continue 1: %assessmentcomplete% 2: %assignmentcomplete% progress
lesson 1: assessments

de-incentivize graham et al (2024) believes that low-stakes, competency, or mastery-based quizzes helps to de-incentivize cheating. image attribution: https://www.pexels.com/photo/schoolchild-solving-elementary-science-test-4022332/

low v. high-stakes low-stakes assessments are not as likely to significantly impact overall course grades like high-stakes assessments. image attribution: https://www.pexels.com/photo/smart-child-solving-test-with-diagrams-4022328/

incorrect you did not select the correct response. there are many things that we can do to prevent students from cheating on quizzes, including the way that we design the quiz. try again try again try again try again try again try again incorrect you did not select the correct response. there are many things that we can do to prevent students from cheating on quizzes, including the way that we design the quiz. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. there are many things that we can do to prevent students from cheating on quizzes, including the way that we design the quiz. continue continue continue continue continue continue true or false directions: select the best answer from the choices provided. when you have answered the question, click the submit button. question: true or false. there is little that we can do to prevent students from cheating on a quiz. true true true false false false

competency-based assessment graham et al (2024) encourages us, where appropriate, to use competency-based assessment. image attribution: https://images.pexels.com/photos/5428146/pexels-photo-5428146.jpeg?auto= compress&cs=tinysrgb&w=600

low stakes assessment low-stakes assessments do not comprise a large percentage of the course grade. image attribution: https://images.pexels.com/photos/7947703/pexels-photo-7947703.jpeg?auto=compress&cs=tinysrgb&w=600

high stakes assessment high-stakes assessments can significantly impact a student’s course grade and are most commonly spaced exams or finals. image attribution: https://www.pexels.com/photo/student-getting-a-mark-in-her-exam-7092548/

incorrect that is incorrect. please try again. try again try again try again try again try again try again incorrect you did not select the correct response. we can combat academic dishonesty on quizzes and exams by using a proctor, creating competency-based assessments, or by giving weekly low-stakes quizzes. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! we can combat academic dishonesty on quizzes and exams by using a proctor, creating competency-based assessments, or by giving weekly low-stakes quizzes. continue continue continue continue continue continue choose all that apply directions: select the best answer from the choices provided. this question has more than one answer. when you are finished, click the submit button. question: what are some ways to combat academic dishonesty on quizzes and exams? choose all that apply create competency-based assessments create competency-based assessments create competency-based assessments give weekly low-stakes quizzes give weekly low-stakes quizzes give weekly low-stakes quizzes give 2 exams worth 40% of the course grade (80% total) give 2 exams worth 40% of the course grade (80% total) give 2 exams worth 40% of the course grade (80% total) use a proctor use a proctor use a proctor

incorrect that is incorrect. please try again. try again try again try again try again try again try again incorrect you did not select the correct response. low-stakes quizzes are worth a small percentage of the final course grade. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. low-stakes quizzes are worth a small percentage of the final course grade. continue continue continue continue continue continue true or false directions: select the best answer from the choices provided. when you are finished, click the submit button. question: true or false. low-stakes quizzes are worth a very small percentage of the final course grade. true true true false false false
lesson 2: assignments

intentional or not plagiarism may occur in several different ways; it’s important to recognize that not all instances are intentional. image attribution: https://www.pexels.com/photo/unrecognizable-hacker-with-smartphone-typing-on-laptop- at-desk-5935791/
to build assignments that combat plagiarism, we need to be aware of strategies that can be used. assignments image attribution: https://www.pexels.com/photo/person-writing-on-a-notebook-4240497/

incorrect that is incorrect. please try again. try again try again try again try again try again try again incorrect you did not select the correct response. students can use any of the ways listed to commit academic dishonesty. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. students can use any of the ways listed to commit academic dishonesty. continue continue continue continue continue continue choose all that apply directions: choose the best answers from the boxes below. more than one answer is correct. when you are finished, click the submit button. question: what are some ways that students commit academic dishonesty on assignments? choose all that apply mix copied/pasted website text in with their own work mix copied/pasted website text in with their own work mix copied/pasted website text in with their own work paraphrase articles without citations paraphrase articles without citations paraphrase articles without citations use ai to write their paper use ai to write their paper use ai to write their paper use an essay mill to write their paper use an essay mill to write their paper use an essay mill to write their paper

combatting plagiarism now that we know some ways that students commit academic dishonesty, let’s look at how we can prevent it. image attribution: https://www.pexels.com/photo/shallow-focus-photo-of-students-cheating-during-an-exam-7092530/

combatting essay mills we can combat essay mills by assigning shorter papers or by breaking longer papers down into smaller chunks. image attribution: https://www.pexels.com/photo/people-working-in-the-office-7438096/

combatting ai ai can easily be used for paper/essay generation, but it can be recognized by plagiarism-detection software. image attribution: https://www.pexels.com/photo/view-of-a-laptop-displaying-chatgpt-15940009//
combatting copy/paste website information may be copy/pasted into the document, but interspersed with the student’s original work.

incorrect that is incorrect. please try again. try again try again try again try again try again try again incorrect you did not select the correct response. all of these things can be used to combat academic dishonesty. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. all of these things can be used to combat academic dishonesty. continue continue continue continue continue continue choose the best answer directions: select the best answer from the choices provided. when you have answered the question, click the submit button. question: we can combat academic dishonesty by ______. all of the above all of the above all of the above requiring students to incorporate feedback into their papers requiring students to incorporate feedback into their papers requiring students to incorporate feedback into their papers using plagiarism-detection software using plagiarism-detection software using plagiarism-detection software breaking longer papers up into smaller sections breaking longer papers up into smaller sections breaking longer papers up into smaller sections
building assignments there are many ways that we can build our assignments to combat academic dishonesty.
integration phase
case study activity let’s apply what we have learned.
select your avatar laura brandon

case study instructions in this section, you will observe a scenario that covers turnitin reports, plagiarism, and designing assignments and assessments that discourage academic dishonesty. when asked, select or provide the best answer. you must complete the scenario before continuing on in the lesson.

case study scenario classes have been in session for a little over 8 weeks. students in your co-worker’s course have had 1 exam and 1 paper due. several of the exam scores are suspiciously high, and some of the papers have returned abnormal turnitin reports. your co-worker has reached out to you because they know that you recently completed this course on discouraging academic dishonesty and are hoping that you have a solution. the following conversation ensues. click the blue play button to begin and move through the conversation.

how can this be discouraged? directions: on the next slide, drag and drop all of the ideas to either the chalkboard or the recycle bin. separate the ideas for discouraging academic dishonesty in assignments into good ideas and bad ideas. good ideas should be dropped on the chalkboard, bad ideas should be dropped in the recycle bin.

incorrect that is incorrect. please try again. try again try again try again try again try again try again incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue good ideas bad ideas require students to submit drafts for feedback require students to submit drafts for feedback require students to submit drafts for feedback require students to submit drafts for feedback require reflection papers require reflection papers require reflection papers require reflection papers break up paper into smaller sections break up paper into smaller sections break up paper into smaller sections break up paper into smaller sections discuss citations in class discuss citations in class discuss citations in class discuss citations in class provide resources that assist with proper citations provide resources that assist with proper citations provide resources that assist with proper citations provide resources that assist with proper citations require students implement feedback require students implement feedback require students implement feedback require students implement feedback talk about plagiarism talk about plagiarism talk about plagiarism talk about plagiarism require turnitin percentages to be less than 5% require turnitin percentages to be less than 5% require turnitin percentages to be less than 5% require turnitin percentages to be less than 5% require papers to be 20 pages long require papers to be 20 pages long require papers to be 20 pages long require papers to be 20 pages long

summative assessment we are going to wrap up our time today with a short summative assessment over the topics that we have covered. quiz time

certificate information once you have successfully completed the assessment, you will receive a certificate of completion. please enter your name as you would like it to show on your certificate type your name here

quiz information overview: this quiz will cover topics covered by today’s lesson. once you have completed the quiz you will receive your score. to successfully complete this lesson, you must score above 80%. scores below 80% must complete a remedial module and retake the quiz. directions: answer each question to the best of your ability and click submit to log your answers. feedback: once you have achieved a score above 80% you will be able to review any questions that you may have missed. when the lesson has been fully completed, you will be able to view or print your certificate of completion.

resource.title: 25 Strategies to Prevent Plagiarism by Sarah Elaine Eaton

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: <Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Hello. My name is Trista Sears. Today we are going to explore Discouraging Academic Dishonesty through Design. When you are ready to get started, click Next in the lower right corner of the screen." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="To help you make the most of today’s lesson, you will want to turn off your phone, close your door, and let those around you know that you will be unavailable for a while." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="To participate fully in this lesson, you will need access to a computer, a robust internet connection, and speakers or headphones." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="To successfully complete this lesson, you will need to fully complete both modules and all learning activities. You will also need to score an 80% on the summative assessment at the end of the lesson." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="I introduced myself at the beginning of the presentation. Let me introduce you to Atsumi. Atsumi will help out with some of the activities that you will complete. Please let us know who you are by filling out the nametag." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Let’s take a moment and think about how much of a problem we think academic dishonesty is in higher education. Using the slider, click and drag the slider to indicate how much of a problem you think academic dishonesty is.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Let’s take a moment and think about how much of a problem we think academic dishonesty is in higher education. Using the slider, click and drag the slider to indicate how much of a problem you think academic dishonesty is." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Dr. Donald McCabe and others, in a study of more than 5,000 graduate business students in the US and Canada, found that 56% of the students admitted to some form of academic dishonesty in the past year. McCabe and his associates also speculate that this number may be significantly higher due to differences in what students perceive as academic dishonesty when using online resources." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="TurnItIn is a plagiarism-detection software that generates a Similarity Report for written assignments. In today’s lesson, I will give a brief overview of TurnItIn, the information provided by the Similarity Report, and how to use the information. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="I will also talk about ways to discourage academic dishonesty and how to create assessments and assignments that do just that." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Hopefully, you were able to come up with a few ideas. If you were not able to, don’t worry you will have a few ideas by the end of the video." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="To begin, click on Module 1. Module 2 will unlock once Module 1 has been completed. Once you have completed Module 2, click the Finish Button to be taken to the summative quiz at the end.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Design Notes:
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="States will be applied to the Continue Arrow and Module 2. Module 2 will unlock after Module 1 has been completed and the Continue Arrow will unlock after Module 2 has been completed. Clicking Continue arrow will send learner to Slide 62." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="When we talk about plagiarism-detection software like TurnItIn, it can bring up many feelings about the need for the software, the software itself, ourselves, and our students. Let’s complete a drag and drop activity exploring those feelings. On the next slide, drag the statements that best represent your feelings about the implementation of TurnItIn to the My Feelings box. When you are finished, click Submit." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Drag and drop the statements that best represent your feelings to the question, “What are your feelings on the implementation of TurnItIn?” Click Submit when you are done." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="As we discussed earlier, TurnItIn is a plagiarism-detection software that is commonly used in educational settings. Our institution has purchased a TurnItIn subscription and it has been integrated into Canvas and will be applied to written assignments like reflections, papers, and final projects." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="According to TurnItIn’s website, it compares a student’s submitted work against content databases, other student papers, internet archives, and scholarly publication. TurnItIn’s databases are massive comparing the student’s work to almost 50 billion different original sources." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="The Similarity Report is the result of the comparisons of the student’s work against the TurnItIn databases." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Click on the Question Marks to explore the different sections of the TurnItIn Similarity Report. Click Next when you are finished." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="We must use our discretion when interpreting Similarity Scores. High scores do not always indicate plagiarism and low scores do not always mean that the work is original. High similarity scores can be obtained if the assignment requires a template or other common framework. The use of common phrases can also be tagged in the Similarity Report as not original work. As faculty, we must look deeper at the Similarity Report to see what is being picked up instead of blindly assuming that a high similarity score always equals plagiarism." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Students can use several strategies to get work that is not original through TurnItIn. Text can be replaced with similar looking characters from the Greek or Armenian character sets. Another strategy that can be used is substituting spaces for letters in white or a color that matches the document background. The passage on this screen has replaced characters, take a few minutes and see if you can find them. Click next when you have finished reviewing the text." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="TurnItIn is really good at picking up character substitutions. The substituted characters are highlighted by TurnItIn from the passage that you just examined. Characters are substituted in hopes that TurnItIn will read the word as nonsense and skip over it. TurnItIn is also able to identify hidden text. This is used in hopes that TurnItIn will see the text as one long word and not a sentence." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Replaced characters, hidden text, and non-standard spellings of words are identified in the Flags for Review section of the Report. You can further explore what TurnItIn identified by clicking on the flag." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="If a student uses an essay mill or a ghost writer, TurnItIn may classify the document as original. But, if a student uses ChatGPT or another AI software to write their paper, TurnItIn can detect this in the AI Report section of the Similarity Report." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Academic dishonesty can be discouraged through the design of the assessments and assignments. The strategies that we choose to use may depend on " /> <Span Text="our " /> <Span Text="goal" /> <Span Text="s." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Don’t be afraid to talk to your students about academic dishonesty. Gently, let them know that you are informed of ways that students can commit academic dishonesty and steps that are being taken to prevent it from occurring (Eaton, 2020). It is important to get this information out in the open because it shows that you, as the instructor recognize what can happen and that you know what to look for. This in and of itself may make those who may have been considering engaging in dishonest academic behaviors think twice." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Graham et al (2024) believes that low-stakes, competency, or mastery-based quizzes helps to de-incentivize cheating. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Low-stakes assessments are not as likely to significantly impact overall course grades like high-stakes assessments. The removal of the possibility of significant impact to overall course grade helps to de-incentivize academic dishonesty." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Let’s pause and answer a few quick questions to gauge our understanding of assessment design to discourage academic dishonesty. The next several slides will contain questions, select the best answer from the choices provided. When you are finished, click the submit button.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Question: True or False. There is little that we can do to prevent students from cheating on a quiz.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Design Notes: 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Atsumi will be present when feedback is given.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="When student clicks submit, maintain slide with student answer and provide the feedback below depending on answer.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="If student answered False, display “You’re correct, (Name)!” “There are many strategies that we can use to discourage students from cheating on a quiz.”
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="If student answered True, display, “Incorrect answer.” “There are many strategies that we can use to discourage students from cheating on a quiz.”
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Once feedback has been given, Submit Button will change to Continue arrow. See slide 46.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Graham et al (2024) encourages us, where appropriate, to use competency-based assessment. This style of assessment focuses on the student’s ability to apply the material that they have learned. This makes it more difficult for students to cheat because we are forcing them to take the material one step farther than simply regurgitating the material for a quiz." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Low-stakes assessments do not comprise a large percentage of the course grade; these assessments may even be open resource. According to Graham and others (2024), these assessments can be most effective when they provide students with real-time feedback, allow multiple attempts, and focus on the student’s mastery of the material. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="High-stakes assessments can significantly impact a student’s course grade and are most commonly spaced exams, mid-terms, or finals. Since these assessments can have such an impact on a student’s course outcome, it is important to look at ways in which we can discourage academic dishonesty. One way that we can discourage academic dishonesty on exams is to create new exams each year. If we are teaching in a hybrid format, we can require students to complete an in-class/on-campus exam, perhaps during Intensive Week, using an in-class proctor or we can use online proctoring for fully online courses (Graham et al., 2024). Online proctoring software uses the student’s browser history and webcam audio/video during the testing period to monitor for cheating; some software will take pictures of the student at random intervals for analysis (Gomez, n.d.). If we do not want to or are unable to use proctoring for our online exams, we can consider creating open note/book exams with a reasonable time limit. Exams of this nature require the student to have considerable knowledge of the material because there is not enough time to look up every answer. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Select the best answer from the choices provided. This question has more than one answer. When you are finished, click the submit button.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Question: What are some ways to combat academic dishonesty on quizzes and exams? Choose all that apply
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LeadingMargin="225" FirstLineMargin="144" StyleKey="Paragraph"> <ListStyle ListType="ListNumberAsUCLetter" ListTypeFormat="Period" Start="0" Color="#000000,00" Size="100" BulletChar="•" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="Use a proctor
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LeadingMargin="225" FirstLineMargin="144" StyleKey="Paragraph"> <ListStyle ListType="ListNumberAsUCLetter" ListTypeFormat="Period" Start="2" Color="#000000,00" Size="100" BulletChar="•" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="Create competency-based assessments
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LeadingMargin="225" FirstLineMargin="144" StyleKey="Paragraph"> <ListStyle ListType="ListNumberAsUCLetter" ListTypeFormat="Period" Start="3" Color="#000000,00" Size="100" BulletChar="•" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="Give 2 exams, worth 40% of the course grade (80% total)
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LeadingMargin="225" FirstLineMargin="144" StyleKey="Paragraph"> <ListStyle ListType="ListNumberAsUCLetter" ListTypeFormat="Period" Start="4" Color="#000000,00" Size="100" BulletChar="•" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="Give weekly low-stakes quizzes
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Design Notes:
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Provide unlimited tries to obtain correct answer. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Atsumi will be present when feedback is given.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="When student clicks submit, display student answer and the following feedback.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="If 1 of A, B, or D is selected provide feedback of “(Name), you are on the right track, try again.”
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="If 2 of A, B, or D is selected provide feedback of “(Name), so close, try again.”
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="If A, B, and D are selected provide feedback of “(Name), you are correct.”
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="If C is selected by itself, provide feedback of “Incorrect Answer” “Two exams totaling 80% of the course grade would be considered a high-stakes exams and may encourage academic dishonesty.”
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="If C is selected in conjunction with another answer, provide feedback of “One of the answers you have selected is incorrect, please try again.”
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Only allow proceed with clicking Submit if A, B, and D are answered. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Once Correct Answer feedback has been given, Submit Button will change to Continue arrow. See Slide 48." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Select the best answer from the choices provided. When you are finished, click the submit button.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Question: True or False. Low-stakes quizzes are worth very small percentages of the final course grade.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="

" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="

" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="

" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="

" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="If student answered True, display, “Incorrect answer.” “Low-stakes quizzes are worth very small percentages of the final course grade because they are not making or breaking the final grade in the course, there is little incentive to cheat.”
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Once feedback has been given, Submit Button will change to Continue arrow. Clicking continue will send student to Slide 38." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Plagiarism may occur in several different ways. It is important to recognize that not all instances of plagiarism are intentional. Sometimes, students inadvertently plagiarize through sloppy citations or extensive paraphrasing without citing the original source. We can head this off at the pass by dedicating class time to discussing references and how to appropriately cite sources (Eaton 2020). It is also helpful to provide students with resources that will provide further guidance on citations and references like the Writing Center or an Online Writing Lab.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="To build assignments that combat plagiarism, we need to be aware of strategies that can be used. Once we are familiar with ways that students can commit academic dishonesty on assignments, we can use this knowledge to create assignments that make it difficult to use those strategies. Students may use artificial intelligence (AI), paper/essay mills, or copying/pasting from websites.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Select the best answer from the choices provided. More than one answer is correct. When you are finished, click the submit button.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Question: What some ways that students commit academic dishonesty on assignments? Choose all that apply
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LeadingMargin="225" FirstLineMargin="144" StyleKey="Paragraph"> <ListStyle ListType="ListNumberAsUCLetter" ListTypeFormat="Period" Start="0" Color="#000000,00" Size="100" BulletChar="•" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="Use an essay mill to write their paper
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LeadingMargin="225" FirstLineMargin="144" StyleKey="Paragraph"> <ListStyle ListType="ListNumberAsUCLetter" ListTypeFormat="Period" Start="2" Color="#000000,00" Size="100" BulletChar="•" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="Paraphrase articles without citations
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LeadingMargin="225" FirstLineMargin="144" StyleKey="Paragraph"> <ListStyle ListType="ListNumberAsUCLetter" ListTypeFormat="Period" Start="3" Color="#000000,00" Size="100" BulletChar="•" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="Use AI to write their paper
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LeadingMargin="225" FirstLineMargin="144" StyleKey="Paragraph"> <ListStyle ListType="ListNumberAsUCLetter" ListTypeFormat="Period" Start="4" Color="#000000,00" Size="100" BulletChar="•" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="Mix copied and pasted website text in with their own work
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Design Notes:
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Provide unlimited tries to obtain correct answer. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Atsumi will be present when feedback is given.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="When student clicks submit, display student answer and the following feedback.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="If 1 of A, B, C, or D is selected, provide feedback of “(Name), you are on the right track, try again.”
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="If 2 of A, B, C, or D is selected, provide feedback of “(Name), so close, try again.”
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="If 3 of A, B, C, or D are selected, provide feedback of “(Name), very close, keep going.”
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="If all 4 are selected, provide feedback of “(Name), you are correct.”
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Only allow proceed to next slide with clicking Submit if A, B, C, and D are answered. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Now that we know some ways that students commit academic dishonesty, let’s look at how we can prevent it." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="We can combat essay mills by assigning shorter papers or by breaking longer papers down into smaller chunks or drafts. This allows us to give feedback along the way with the expectation that it is incorporated into the final product. Essay mills typically have a minimum paper length of 5 pages (Eaton, 2020). If we assign papers that are shorter than this threshold it may decrease the student’s reliance on these services. Likewise, essay mills are notoriously bad at writing reaction/reflection papers and papers by section, especially, if we require that they incorporate our feedback into the assignment." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="AI can easily be used for paper/essay generation, but it is also very easily recognized by plagiarism-detection software. TurnItIn generates a percentage of work that was generated through AI in the Flags tab. We can also use many of the essay mill strategies to combat the use of AI. AI is not good at creating reflection papers, papers by chunk, and project-based work (Tsu, 2024)." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Website information may be copy/pasted into the document, but interspersed with the student’s original work. Northern Illinois University (n. d.)refers to this as patchwork plagiarism. This type of plagiarism is easily detected by plagiarism-detection software programs like TurnItIn and is shown on the Similarity Report with the original source." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Let’s pause and answer a few quick questions to gauge our understanding of assignment design to discourage academic dishonesty. The next several slides will contain questions, select the best answer from the choices provided. When you are finished, click the submit button.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Question: We can combat academic dishonesty by ______.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LeadingMargin="153" FirstLineMargin="72" StyleKey="Paragraph"> <ListStyle ListType="ListNumberAsUCLetter" ListTypeFormat="Period" Start="0" Color="#000000,00" Size="100" BulletChar="•" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="Breaking longer papers up into smaller sections.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LeadingMargin="153" FirstLineMargin="72" StyleKey="Paragraph"> <ListStyle ListType="ListNumberAsUCLetter" ListTypeFormat="Period" Start="2" Color="#000000,00" Size="100" BulletChar="•" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="Using plagiarism-detection software
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LeadingMargin="153" FirstLineMargin="72" StyleKey="Paragraph"> <ListStyle ListType="ListNumberAsUCLetter" ListTypeFormat="Period" Start="3" Color="#000000,00" Size="100" BulletChar="•" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="Requiring students to incorporate feedback into their papers
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style LeadingMargin="153" FirstLineMargin="72" StyleKey="Paragraph"> <ListStyle ListType="ListNumberAsUCLetter" ListTypeFormat="Period" Start="4" Color="#000000,00" Size="100" BulletChar="•" BulletFont="Arial"> <BulletPicture Size="0x0" /> </ListStyle> </Style> <Span Text="All of the above
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Design Notes: 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Atsumi will be present when feedback is given.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Unlimited attempts for correct answer.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="When student clicks submit, maintain slide with student answer and provide the feedback below depending on answer.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="If student answered D, display “You’re correct, (Name)!” “These are all strategies that we can use to discourage students from engaging in academic dishonesty on assignments.”
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="If student answered anything other than D, display “Incorrect answer.” “Please try again.”
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Once feedback has been given, Submit Button will change to Continue arrow. See slide 46.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="There are many ways that we can build our assignments to combat academic dishonesty. We can assign shorter papers, give reflection assignments, break larger papers down into smaller sections or drafts, and use plagiarism-detection software as a tool to help us recognize when content may not be the student’s original work.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Design Note:
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Clicking Continue Arrow returns learner to Slide 39." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Let’s apply what we have learned. Throughout the lesson, we have learned about TurnItIn, plagiarism, and ways to create assignments and assessments to discourage academic dishonesty. Atsumi is going to help us out in our case study scenarios by playing the part of your co-worker.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Design Notes:
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="I plan to modify either ScenarioInterview by Trina Rimmer or ScenarioTemplate by Nicole LeGault for the case scenarios. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Link for ScenarioInterview: https://360.articulate.com/review/content/81d07c31-fe0c-4965-ba7f-18faef185b1e/review
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Link for ScenarioTemplate: https://articulate-heroes-authoring.s3.amazonaws.com/Nicole/Downloads/SL2-Scenario-Template/output/story_html5.html
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="-- Learner will select their character" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="In the following scenario you will be part of an interaction between " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Classes have been in session for a little over 8 weeks. Students in your co-worker’s course have had 1 exam and 1 paper due. Several of the exam scores are suspiciously high, and several of the papers display TurnItIn Reports. Your co-worker has reached out to you because they know that you recently completed this course on Discouraging Academic Dishonesty and are hoping that you have a solution. The following conversation ensues. Click the blue play button to move through the conversation." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Design Note: Dialog will be click to reveal.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="

" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Atsumi: What does this mean?
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="On the next several slides, you will be asked to answer questions to help interpret each report. Select the best answer. To view the report again, click on the links provided on the bottom of the slides." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Design Note: Dialog will be click to reveal.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Dialog
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Atsumi: (looking defeated) Ugh! What can I do to keep this from happening in the future?
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="(Name): I’m so glad that you asked." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="On the next slide, drag and drop all of the ideas to either the chalkboard or the recycle bin. Good ideas should be dropped on the chalkboard, bad ideas should be dropped in the recycle bin." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Design Note: Dialog will be click to reveal.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Dialog
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Atsumi: Wow! This is really helpful. Do you have any thoughts about the exam performance in my class?
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="(Name): Well, let’s think about it.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Atsumi: Ok
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Design Note: Dialog will be click to reveal.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Dialog
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Atsumi: (looking encouraged) Thank you. This has been very helpful.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="(Name): Anytime. Glad I could help." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="We are going to wrap up our time today with a short summative assessment over the topics that we have covered." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Once you have successfully completed the assessment, you will receive a certificate of completion. Please enter your name as you would like for it to show on your certificate of completion. Click Submit when you are finished.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Design Note:
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="If Yes is clicked then skip to Slide 89.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="If No is clicked, proceed to Slide 88." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="This quiz will cover topics covered by today’s lesson. Once you have completed the quiz you will receive your score. To successfully complete this lesson, you must score above 80%. Scores below 80% must complete a remedial module and retake the quiz. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Answer each question to the best of your ability and click Submit to log your answers.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Once you have achieved a score above 80% you will be able to review any questions that you may have missed. When the lesson has been fully completed, you will be provided a link to view/print your Certificate of Completion.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Ultimately, the prevention of academic dishonesty begins with the education of ourselves and our students. We can implement several strategies when designing assessments and assignments to discourage academic dishonesty." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="We have covered quite a few ways to prevent plagiarism and academic dishonesty, but there are more strategies out there. Sarah Eaton (2020) has compiled a list of “25 Strategies to Prevent Plagiarism.” This list is a good start and gives us many things to think about as we look at redesigning our assignments and assessments. You can find this list by clicking on the " /> <Span Text="link or on Resources in the upper right corner of your screen" /> <Span Text="." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Here is the list of resources that I used in making the lesson. I encourage you to check a few of them out if you would like explore the topics that I covered in more depth." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Thank you for watching. Click the purple button to View or Print your Certificate of Completion." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Don’t be afraid to talk to your students about academic dishonesty. Gently, let them know that you are informed of ways that students can commit academic dishonesty and steps that are " /> <Span Text="being " /> <Span Text="taken to prevent it from occurring (Eaton, 2020). It is important to get this information out in the open because it shows that you, as the instructor recognize what can happen and that you know what to look for. This in and of itself may make those who may have been considering engaging in dishonest" /> <Span Text=" academic" /> <Span Text=" behaviors think twice." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="The Similarity Report is the result of the comparisons of the student’s work against the TurnItIn databases." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Replaced characters, hidden text, and non-standard spellings of words are identified in the Flags for Review section of the Report. You can further explore what TurnItIn identified by clicking on the flag." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="To build assignments that combat plagiarism, we need to be aware of strategies that can be used. Once we are familiar with ways that students can commit academic dishonesty on assignments, we can use this knowledge to create assignments that make it difficult to use those strategies. Students may use artificial intelligence (AI), paper/essay mills, or copying/pasting from websites.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="We can combat essay mills by assigning shorter papers or by breaking longer papers down into smaller chunks or drafts. This allows us to give feedback along the way with the expectation that it is incorporated into the final product. Essay mills typically have a minimum paper length of 5 pages (Eaton, 2020). If we assign papers that are shorter than this threshold it may decrease the student’s reliance on these services. Likewise, essay mills are notoriously bad at writing reaction/reflection papers and papers by section, especially, if we require that they incorporate our feedback into the assignment." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="AI can easily be used for paper/essay generation, but it is also very easily recognized by plagiarism-detection software. TurnItIn generates a percentage of work that was generated through AI in the Flags tab. We can also use many of the essay mill strategies to combat the use of AI. AI is not good at creating reflection papers, papers by chunk, and project-based work (Tsu, 2024)." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="If a student uses an essay mill or a ghost writer, TurnItIn may classify the document as original. But, if a student uses ChatGPT or another AI software to write their paper, TurnItIn can detect this in the AI Report section of the Similarity Report." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Graham et al (2024) believes that low-stakes, competency, or mastery-based quizzes helps to de-incentivize cheating. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Low-stakes assessments do not comprise a large percentage of the course grade; these assessments may even be open resource. According to Graham and others (2024), these assessments can be most effective when they provide students with real-time feedback, allow multiple attempts, and focus on the student’s mastery of the material. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="Graham et al (2024) encourages us, where appropriate, to use competency-based assessment. This style of assessment focuses on the student’s ability to apply the material that they have learned. This makes it more difficult for students to cheat because we are forcing them to take the material one step farther than simply regurgitating the material for a quiz." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="Paragraph" /> <Span Text="High-stakes assessments can significantly impact a student’s course grade and are most commonly spaced exams, mid-terms, or finals. Since these assessments can have such an impact on a student’s course outcome, it is important to look at ways in which we can discourage academic dishonesty. One way that we can discourage academic dishonesty on exams is to create new exams each year. If we are teaching in a hybrid format, we can require students to complete an in-class/on-campus exam, perhaps during Intensive Week, using an in-class proctor or we can use online proctoring for fully online courses (Graham et al., 2024). Online proctoring software uses the student’s browser history and webcam audio/video during the testing period to monitor for cheating; some software will take pictures of the student at random intervals for analysis (Gomez, n.d.). If we do not want to or are unable to use proctoring for our online exams, we can consider creating open note/book exams with a reasonable time limit. Exams of this nature require the student to have considerable knowledge of the material because there is not enough time to look up every answer. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

terms.term: Academic Dishonesty is a broad term that covers dishonest academic behaviors like plagiarism and cheating.
